awd_titl_txt: BUILDING INCLUSIVE MAKER COMMUNITIES FOR ENGINEERING TECHNOLOGY STUDENTS
awd_abstract_narration:
The Bellingham Technical College "Building Inclusive Maker Communities for Engineering Technology Students" (MakerCETS) project will increase the number of low-income, academically talented STEM students who persist, graduate, and transfer to a four-year program or enter the STEM workforce. The program will provide scholarships, student support services, and help students develop positive identities and technical skills through the development of inclusive, maker-based learning (MBL) communities. Students, faculty and their industry and community partners will collaboratively design maker-based project sequences that integrate technology, innovation, and industry-based research projects into the student experience. Maker-based learning experiences are similar to traditional project-based learning experiences, but extend beyond the classroom through long-term project involvement and direct community connections. The MakerCETS project will provide scholarships for three cohorts of 12 low-income, academically talented students over the course of five years and will focus on connecting these 36 students to their peers and regional engineering technology communities.

The MakerCETS project will increase student access to STEM programs by providing financial assistance and academic support for Engineering Technology program students with the goals of increasing retention, graduation, and transfer rates and improving student workforce placement opportunities. This project will broaden participation in STEM through the development of student support and networking structures and the inclusion of maker-based work that has been shown to increase diversity and is especially attractive to women. Participants will engage in an MBL sequence, create individualized educational and career plans, build strong academic communities and workforce networks, have access to robust placement support services, and benefit from seamless transfer opportunities to BTC's new Baccalaureate of Applied Science in Engineering Technology and Western Washington University's College of Science & Engineering. Project staff will investigate the impact this maker-inspired, community building approach has on success rates and perceived self-efficacy for STEM students and use results to inform and disseminate the creation of an adaptable, replicable student engagement and support model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Building Inclusive Maker Communities for Engineering Technology Students (MakerCETS) project (DUE 1741540) was a six-year project awarded in March 2018 for $649,482, ending in February 2024.  The program was conducted at Bellingham Technical College (BTC) which is located in Bellingham, Washington U.S.A.  The goal of the project was to improve the graduation and professional placement rates of low-income, academically talented engineering technology students by providing:

  • Substantial scholarships that allowed students to mitigate/work/life balance and persist in their academic endeavors.
  • Engage student participants with project-based learning (PBL) communities in the form of year-long community engineering service projects.
  • Faculty mentoring, academic support, and both career and upper-division transfer advising.

The MakerCETs program included four student cohorts of approximately twelve students per year for academic years 2019-2020 through 2022-2023.  Students had the option of participating for either one or two years.  Eligibility requirements included the following with preference given to eligible applicants from groups currently underrepresented in STEM disciplines.

  • Demonstration of academic excellence (GPA of 3.0 or higher) or an outstanding professional work history
  • Economically challenged (Pell Grant Eligible)
  • Full-time students pursuing an Engineering Technology Associates or Applied Bachelor’s degree.  During the second year, the program was opened to part-time students.

The demographics of MakerCETs student participants compared to BTC’s general engineering technology student population are summarizing in Figure 1.  The MakerCETs student demographics were representative of the general engineering technology student population with the following statistically significant exceptions (ANOVA P < 0.05):

  • The proportion of MakerCETs students disclosing disabilities or choosing not to disclose disability status was higher than that of the general engineering technology student population.
  • The proportion of MakerCETs students identifying as white non-hispanic was higher compared to the general engineering technology student population.
  • Compared to the general engineering technology student population, the proportion of MakerCETs students under the age of 30 was lower, and the proportion of MakerCETs students between 30-39 was higher.

Among the MakerCETs student participants, a qualitative (non-statistical) assessment of graduation and persistence (Figures 2-3) showed:

  • Higher graduation rates for female versus male students
  • Higher graduation rates for nondisabled students versus students with a disability or opting not to disclose their disability status.
  • Lower graduation rates and higher withdrawal rates for students with commutes to BTC campus greater than 15 miles versus those with shorter commutes to campus.
  • Lower graduation rates for students under age 30 versus students over age 30 at the time of entry into the MakerCETs program.
  • Progressive increase in graduation rate and STEM job placement with increasing levels of prior academic experience.

 

All MakerCETs students were required to participate in a year-long community engineering service project which counted as a graded course applicable to their elective graduation requirements.  For the service projects, students formed teams of 2-4 students and provided technical support to a non-profit or government partner dedicated to solving a local or regional humanitarian or environmental problem.  Student teams were responsible for identification of and liaising with their community partners, using the iterative engineering design process to identify functional specifications and performance criteria essential for technical project success and community partner satisfaction.  Student projects included a wide range of deliverables including CAD designs, manufacturing and sourcing plans, topographic surveys, GIS maps, and fabricated equipment.  Feedback from the community partners was positive with a high rate of satisfaction with the projects.  The community engineering service project model has been adopted as the senior capstone course model for BTC’s Bachelor of Applied Science and Engineering Technology program.

In twice-annual surveys, MakerCETs student participants indicated that the scholarships were instrumental to their participation and persistence in their engineering technology programs and reduced the hours they had to work to support themselves.  Students felt that participation in the community engineering service projects improved their confidence in their ability to approach and engage with community members in a professional capacity, apply their academic training in a practical context, communicate technical information, and work as part of an interdisciplinary team.  Nearly all students felt that the availability of academic and professional mentoring from a STEM faculty member was helpful to their success.

A major limitation of the MakerCETs project was the lack of control groups representative of the general BTC engineering technology student population with which to compare the persistence, graduation rates, and STEM placement rates of MakerCETs participants.  Inclusion of controls would have allowed for causal inference regarding the value of future institutional implementation of all or parts of the MakerCETs program.

 


Last Modified: 02/26/2024
Modified by: Laura A Wurth
